intro: Brassica napus var. chinensis, commonly known as Chinese cabbage, is a cultivar of the oilseed rape species. It is a biennial plant that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring thick, fleshy stalks and dark green, lobed leaves. The plant is cultivated for its edible leaves and stems, which are used in various Asian cuisines. It thrives in temperate climates and requires well-drained soil for optimal growth. Chinese cabbage is a member of the Brassicaceae family, known for its cruciferous characteristics and nutritional value.
